title: Stimulus And Inflation Expectations: Tony Greer
text: The new fiscal package from Congress is insufficient but the market is looking past it and past the latest virus news to focus on the reopening. The Fed's MO to inflate assets is a weaker dollar and that directly speaks to commodities rallying.

title: SEC OKs Direct IPO Listings To NYSE
text: Companies seeking to hold initial public offerings (IPOs) on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) no longer will be required to let investment banks buy and sell the first shares to hit the market, the Financial Times (FT) reported. The addition of a lower-cost, underwriter-free IPO option was formally approved by the U.S. Securities and […]

title: Stocks Reverse Higher To Close Off Lows, Stimulus In Limbo?
text: The stock market continues to trade sideways (mixed) yet without a correction. The Nasdaq Composite and Russell 2000 Index continue to hold up well, while defensive stocks struggle to keep up.

title: Trump calls on Congress to amend COVID-19 bill
text: President Trump slammed the recently passed $900 billion COVID-19 relief package as a "disgrace" on Tuesday evening, urging Congress amend the bill to increase the direct payments given to Americans. #FoxBusiness Read more, here: https://www.foxnews.com/politics/trump-threatens-to-veto-massive-covid-bill Subscribe to Fox Business!

title: Donald Trump Rails Against Covid-19 Relief Bill, Asks Congress To Amend Massive Legislation
text: President Donald Trump is balking at the massive $2.3 trillion Covid-19 relief and government funding bills that overwhelming passed Congress and has asked lawmakers to return to amend the bill to increase “ridiculously low” direct payments of $600 per person. Trump has yet to sign the 5,000-plus page legislation, and he spent much of a...

title: Jim Cramer reviews 'dream market' of start-ups targeting the alternative fuel food chain
text: The market for alternative fuels for cars and trucks has incredible momentum, even as it's already ridiculously overheated, the "Mad Money" host said.

title: US Consumer Confidence Drops In December As COVID Cases Surge
text: Consumer confidence fell in December, declining to 88.6 of a possible 100 points from 92.9 in November, according to a Consumer Confidence Survey from The Conference Board. The figure is intended to reflect the attitudes and purchasing plans of consumers across various economic and demographic categories.

title: Some NYSE operations to return to remote working
text: Some of the New York Stock Exchange's operations will temporarily return to remote working from Monday amid the ongoing coronavirus outbreak.

title: Nasdaq & Russell 2K Hit Fresh All-Time Highs
text: The Nasdaq benefited from big days at Peloton (PTON) and Apple (AAPL), while the small-cap Russell 2K index continues to rope in momentum traders.

title: 2021 Outlook Summary: Out of the Darkness
text: RiverFront places a high probability of positive market returns in 2021 2020 was a dark year by almost any standard imaginable. title: Bill Gurley says direct listing rule change will end traditional IPOs
text: "Let's not let these intermediaries and gatekeepers hand allocate who gets this underpriced stock," tech investor Bill Gurley told CNBC.

title: A Very Choppy Day (Technically Speaking For 12/22)
text: The Chicago Fed National Activity Index was lower but still indicated an expansion. The third and final estimate of 3Q20 GDP showed a fairly sharp rebound.

text: CNBC's Bob Pisani reports that the market makers at the New York Stock Exchange will temporarily return to remote work Monday, following the Christmas holiday.

title: Stock futures flat after S&P 500's three-day losing streak
text: Equities slipped on Tuesday despite Congress passing a bill with $900 billion in pandemic aid after months long negations.

title: The DJIA and S&P 500 Slip as Tech Stocks Rise
text: The DJIA tumbled 200 points and the S&P 500 fell for the third day in a row as investors quickly got over the passage of the new stimulus bill and backed away from their recent buying spree of value and cyclical stocks.

title: Some NYSE trading floor personnel to return to remote operations
text: A portion of New York Stock Exchange workers will return to remote working amid a surge in Covid-19 cases in the largest U.S. city.

title: Federal Reserve Watch: In 2021, Continued Support Of Stock Market
text: Investors are now dependent upon the narrative about the Federal Reserve that has been built up in recent years that the Fed will support stock market prices. The current strong belief goes back to the Fed's economic policy put together by former Fed chair Ben Bernanke to get out of the Great Recession and create economic growth.

title: Face Reality: Pit Yourself Against Nasdaq 100
text: Beware how you or your investment advisor measures performance. With recent additions and deletions, the Dow Jones Industrials looks more and more like the S&P 500 Index.

title: The SEC just greenlighted a new way for companies to go public and raise cash. Here's how it works, and why it could transform how hot tech companies think about IPOs.
text: A year after a change was first proposed, the Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday finally greenlighted the New York Stock Exchange's plan to allow companies to raise capital through a direct listing. Direct listings, in which companies can make a public debut but leapfrog the costly underwriting fees required by IPOs, have already been creating a buzz, especially among tech companies that are looking to go public. Until now, though, companies could not raise fresh money in a direct listing.

title: Bill Gurley praises raising capital through direct listing
text: Bill Gurley, Benchmark General Partner, praised the SEC's decision to allow the New York Stock Exchange's plan to allow companies to raise cash via direct listings.

title: The Dow Fell 200 Points Because Stocks Have Run Hot. More Travel Bans Loom.
text: Stocks had a mixed performance Tuesday. Investors were spooked by a Covid-19 mutation in the U.K. that could signal more restrictions on global travel.

title: Markets Are Pricing In a Recovery for 2021: Quadratic's Davis
text: Dec.22 -- Nancy Davis, founder and chief investment officer at Quadratic Capital, talks about her market outlook for 2021 on "Bloomberg Markets."

title: We advise clients to have a 'bar-bell' strategy: Crossmark's Victoria Fernandez
text: Victoria Fernandez, Crossmark global investments, joins 'Closing Bell' to discuss what she's advising investors to do now.

title: Stock Market Today: Nasdaq Sets Fresh Record, But Confidence Is Flagging
text: While COVID stimulus is all but a done deal, concerns about America's extended second wave and U.K.'s mutant strain weighed during a mixed Tuesday session.

title: U.S. Treasury-led report calls for overhaul of money market funds
text: U.S. policymakers need to consider major changes to make money market funds less vulnerable to investor runs, a working group led by the Treasury Department said Tuesday, stopping short of making specific recommendations.

title: Dow Jones Today: Stocks Erase Losses, Coronavirus Variant Vaccine Possible; Apple Thinking Of Apple Car
text: The biggest fear among investors and traders is whether the coronavirus variant is going to be more deadly than the current coronavirus

title: Sentiment is more careful as there is risk for a Covid winter: Eugene Profit
text: Eugene Profit from Profit Investments joins 'Closing Bell' to give his insight on the state of the markets. He also discusses his view on Peloton stocks.

title: US stocks close mixed as stimulus optimism clashes with new virus strain
text: US equities closed mixed on Tuesday as investors weighed Monday's stimulus vote against the emergence of a new coronavirus strain in the UK. Congress approved the measure Monday night after months of negotiations over additional fiscal support. The bill, which includes $900 billion in new stimulus, funds the government through September 30. The package also includes $600 direct payments, $300 in additional federal unemployment benefits, and funds for the Paycheck Protection Program.

title: Nasdaq ends at a record but Dow books worst loss in December as tightened COVID travel curbs sink broader market
text: The Nasdaq Composite logged a record closing high Tuesday but the Dow industrials rang up the worst loss in December as a mutation of the virus that causes COVID-19 strain continued to fuel fresh lockdown measures in parts of Europe, resulting in an apparent pause in bullish sentiment on Wall Street. The Nasdaq closed up 0.5%, enough to log a record finish at around 12,807.

title: SEC approves NYSE plan to allow companies to raise cash through direct listings
text: The SEC has approved the New York Stock Exchange's new type of direct listing that would allow companies to issue new shares and sell them directly to the public on the first day of trading. This would allow companies to raise money on the NYSE without paying big underwriting fees to Wall Street banks.

title: The current state of the U.S. economy as consumer confidence falls
text: Dana Peterson, the chief economist at the Conference Board, on today's weak economic data and what is says about the broader economy.

title: Joe Biden says he will push for more stimulus checks in next Covid relief bill
text: Joe Biden will push for a third round of stimulus checks in the next Covid-19 relief bill.

text: Dec.22 -- Victor Khosla, SVPGlobal founder and chief investment officer, discusses the outlook for distressed markets with Bloomberg's Sonali Basak, Caroline Hyde and Taylor Riggs on "Bloomberg Markets: The Close."

title: There's a huge spread between value and growth: Cornerstone's Kantrowitz
text: Michael Kantrowitz, Cornerstone Macro chief investment strategist, on whether growth stocks will continue to outperform value stocks.

title: Why home prices aren't likely to go down over the winter
text: CNBC's Tyler Mathisen is joined by Tyler Gorman of Coldwell Banker to discuss the hot housing sector and what may be next in 2021.

title: SEC approves NYSE plan for direct listing IPOs
text: CNBC's Leslie Picker reports on how the SEC has approved a rule change for direct listings at the New York Stock Exchange.

text: CNBC's Tyler Mathisen discusses what key market drivers may be in 2021 with Angela Mwanza of UBS and Ernesto Ramos of BMO Capital Management.

title: Another round of stimulus is unlikely: Conference Board CEO Steve Odland
text: The Conference Board CEO Steve Odland joins CNBC's Tyler Mathisen to discuss consumer confidence and what the main concerns are for Americans amid the pandemic.

title: Pandemic, Debt And The End Of Falling Interest Rates
text: Coronavirus vaccines have given the markets hope and propulsion in recent months and now we have our first major COVID-19 mutation. Congress came together on a minimalistic support bill, but it won't be enough for 8 million Americans newly in poverty or the 34 million that were already in poverty.

title: The Tell: Year-end fund rebalancing may explain why stocks aren't rallying despite a $900 billion U.S. fiscal deal
text: Stock markets may have a tough time extending their gains before the end of 2020 as investors take their chips off the table.

title: U.S. approves NYSE listing plan to cut out Wall Street middlemen
text: Companies may go public on the New York Stock Exchange without forking out fat fees to Wall Street banks which typically underwrite such capital raisings, the U.S. securities regulator said on Tuesday.

title: The Most Surprising Measures Congress Rolled In With The Covid Relief Legislation
text: The bill includes unemployment benefits and $600 checks ... and policies on horse racing, Smokey Bear and the Dalai Lama.

title: Markets want certainty over new strain of Covid, expert says
text: Mike Gallagher, Managing Director of Continuum Economics, discusses the economic outlook for 2021.

title: US existing home sales drop for the first time in 6 months amid rising prices and record-low supply
text: Sales of preowned homes in the US contracted for the first time in six months in November as soaring prices and dwindling supply butted heads with the recent housing-market boom. Existing home sales fell 2.5% last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.69 million, the National Association of Realtors said Tuesday. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg expected sales to fall to 6.7 million.

title: The Technical Indicator: Charting a bullish backdrop as the S&P 500's wild 2020 ride concludes
text: Technically speaking, the major U.S. benchmarks have pulled in from recent record highs amid still largely bullish year-end price action, writes Michael Ashbaugh.

title: Report: Hundreds of CFOs optimistic on the macro outlook
text: Just days into 2021, chief financial officers at hundreds of U.S. companies are bullish on the macro environment and expect their businesses to recover in the coming years, The Wall Street Journal reported. CFO survey Duke University's Fuqua School of Business in conjunction with the Federal Reserve Banks of Atlanta and Richmond surveyed around 300 CFOs.

title: 'A banner year': US GDP will grow 6% in 2021 as businesses feel the full effect of pandemic relief policies, says a chief investment strategist
text: Leuthold Group's Jim Paulsen told CNBC on Tuesday that the US economy will have a "banner year" in 2021. The chief investment strategist expects US gross domestic product to grow 6% next year, putting him on the higher end of overall projections. Bank of America, for example, expects GDP expansion of just 4.5% in 2021. Paulsen explained that several pandemic relief policies that were implemented in 2020 won't take effect until 2021. He said typically monetary and fiscal policies take a year or more to have a positive impact on the economy.

title: Existing-Home Sales Dipped in November. Here's Why.
text: The seasonally-adjusted rate of existing-home sales dipped for the first time in five months—and low inventory could be the culprit.

title: US consumer confidence unexpectedly falls to lowest since August as COVID-19 restrictions escalate
text: US consumer confidence dashed expectations in December as soaring COVID-19 cases and warnings of full lockdowns cut into economic outlooks. The Conference Board's index of consumer confidence fell to 88.6 this month from 92.9, according to a Tuesday press release. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg expected the gauge to climb to 97. The reading is the lowest since August. November's reading was also saw a downward revision.

title: Inflation a Point of Worry for 2021 Markets, PGIM's Peters Says
text: Dec.22 -- Greg Peters, senior portfolio manager at PGIM Fixed Income, discusses how inflation concerns could impact markets in 2021. He speaks with Bloomberg's Lisa Abramowicz on "Bloomberg The Open.
